summary: This document is a sealed application and supporting affidavit from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, seeking warrants and orders for prospective and historical cellphone location information and pen register data for two cellphones believed to be used by Ghislaine Maxwell. The application, filed on June 29, 2020, is based on a grand jury indictment and arrest warrant for Maxwell issued the same day, and aims to locate her for arrest on charges related to the sexual exploitation of minors.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who is submitting the application for warrants and orders.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney who prepared and signed the application for warrants and orders.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The primary target of the investigation, indicted on charges of conspiracy, enticement, transportation of minors, and perjury. Believed to use the target cellphones.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and close associate of Ghislaine Maxwell. His phone contained a contact for one of Maxwell's target phones.

persons.name: Joshua Perry
persons.context: Husband of a former Epstein employee. His phone was in contact with one of Maxwell's target phones.

persons.name: Isabel Maxwell
persons.context: Ghislaine Maxwell's sister. Her phone was in contact with both of Maxwell's target phones.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: An attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in civil litigation. Her phone was in contact with Maxwell's target phones.

persons.name: Scott Borgerson
persons.context: Individual with whom Ghislaine Maxwell shares a joint bank account and to whom her Amazon account sent packages. His phone was in contact with Maxwell's target phones.

persons.name: Amanda Young
persons.context: FBI Special Agent who swore the affidavit in support of the warrants, detailing the investigation and probable cause.

persons.name: Lisa Margaret Smith
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who signed the arrest warrant for Ghislaine Maxwell on June 29, 2020.

persons.name: Catharine H. Parker
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who swore in FBI Special Agent Amanda Young and issued the warrants and orders for cellphone tracking.

connections.description: Described as a close associate and employee. Charged with committing crimes together related to the sexual exploitation of minors.
Isabel Maxwell is identified as Ghislaine Maxwell's sister, and their phones were in contact.
Laura Menninger is identified as an attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in civil litigation.
They share a joint bank account, and Maxwell's Amazon account sent packages to Borgerson.
Phone contact between Maxwell's phone and Perry's phone. Perry is the husband of a former Epstein employee.

events.title: Indictment and Arrest Warrant for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: A grand jury in the Southern District of New York returned an indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with conspiracy, enticement, transportation of minors, and perjury. Magistrate Judge Lisa Margaret Smith signed an arrest warrant the same day.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested by the FBI on federal sex trafficking charges. An iPhone was seized from his possession.

events.title: Court Order for Cellphone Tracking
events.description: Magistrate Judge Catharine H. Parker issued warrants and orders authorizing the tracking of two cellphones associated with Ghislaine Maxwell for 45 days of prospective data and historical data from June 1, 2020.

keyFacts: On June 29, 2020, Ghislaine Maxwell was indicted and an arrest warrant was issued for her on charges including conspiracy to entice minors and perjury.

The government sought and obtained sealed warrants to track two cellphones: one subscribed to 'Terramar Project, Inc.' (T-Mobile) and one subscribed to 'G Max' (AT&T), both believed to be used by Maxwell.
Evidence linking Maxwell to the phones includes a contact saved as 'Ghislaine' in Jeffrey Epstein's phone (seized at his arrest) and recent contacts with her sister, attorneys, and associates.

The application argues that premature disclosure of the investigation could lead Maxwell to flee, intimidate witnesses, or destroy evidence, justifying a one-year non-disclosure order to the service providers.
The warrants authorized 45 days of prospective location/pen register tracking and historical data from June 1, 2020, to locate Maxwell for arrest.
